hints.content: Corresponding points on a figure and its image are an equal distance from the line of reflection. Therefore, the line of reflection will pass through the midpoints of the line segments that join corresponding points. It is sufficient to determine two of these midpoints in order to define this line.

The midpoint of the line segment joining point $F(-7,0)$ and its corresponding point $(-5,-6)$ is:

$\qquad\left(\dfrac{-7+(-5)}{2}\,_{\Large,}\,\dfrac{0+(-6)}{2}\right)=(-6,-3)$.  

The midpoint of the line segment joining point $L(1,6)$ and its corresponding point $(5,-6)$ is:

$\qquad\left(\dfrac{1+5}{2}\,_{\Large,}\,\dfrac{6+(-6)}{2}\right)=(3,0)$.


Therefore the line of reflection must pass through the points $(-6,-3)$ and $(3,0)$, as shown below. These points define the line $y = \dfrac{1}{3}x-1$.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/53a4a4f2520246c63137aff7345326f85c81bab5)
From our work above, the points $(-6,-3)$ and $(3,0)$ lie on the line of reflection $y = \dfrac{1}{3}x-1$, although any two distinct points of the form $\left(a,\dfrac{a}{3}-1\right)$ will work.
